needs.description: Delhi reported 12,450 dengue cases and 28 deaths in 2025, with hospitals operating at 112% capacity during peak monsoon season. The WHO noted a 40% increase in vector-borne diseases compared to 2024, straining ICU availability.
Over 1.2M residents lack access to piped water in unauthorized colonies, relying on contaminated groundwater. UNICEF reported 23% of water samples tested positive for fecal coliform in 2025.
Urban flooding in July 2025 displaced 45,000 people in low-lying areas, with 12,000 still in temporary shelters as of January 2026. IOM estimates 60% of displaced households lack adequate sanitation.

needs.description: Maharashtra recorded 18,750 malaria cases in 2025, with Mumbai accounting for 42% of cases. The city's public hospitals face a shortage of 1,200 doctors and 2,800 nurses, according to the State Health Department.
IPC analysis shows 1.1M people in Mumbai's slums are in IPC Phase 2 (Stressed), with 230,000 in Phase 3 (Crisis). WFP reported a 15% increase in food voucher distribution compared to 2024.
Monsoon flooding in 2025 damaged 3,200 km of roads and 450 bridges in Maharashtra, disrupting access to healthcare and markets. Repair costs estimated at $1.2B by the state government.

needs.description: Chennai faced a severe water crisis in 2025, with reservoir levels dropping to 19% capacity. UNICEF reported 2.4M people relying on water tankers, with 35% of samples testing unsafe for consumption.
Tamil Nadu recorded 9,200 chikungunya cases in 2025, with Chennai accounting for 58% of cases. The state health department reported a shortage of 800 hospital beds in the city.

Cyclone Michaung in December 2023 displaced 75,000 people in Tamil Nadu, with 12,000 still in relief camps as of February 2026. IOM estimates 40% of displaced households lack durable housing solutions.

needs.description: West Bengal reported 6,800 Japanese encephalitis cases in 2025, with Kolkata accounting for 35% of cases. The state health department noted a 25% increase in encephalitis-related deaths compared to 2024.
IPC data shows 850,000 people in West Bengal are in IPC Phase 2 (Stressed), with 180,000 in Phase 3 (Crisis). WFP reported a 12% increase in malnutrition rates among children under 5.
Floods in September 2025 displaced 60,000 people in West Bengal, with 8,000 still in temporary shelters. IOM estimates 50% of displaced households lack access to clean water.
